presentation.title: API Strategy Execution
presentation.toc: APIs are getting recognized as being strategic in many organizations, and yet there often isn't an explicit API strategy or program in place. As the API sector matures there are emerging patterns how to approach API strategies and programs within organizations. Depending on how far along on their API journey an organization is, there are various patterns and none of those are right or wrong, they just are different stages in the strategic use of APIs. We look at some of these patterns and will look at them in the context of API strategies and their execution.

blockquote.p: Digital Transformation means adapting an organization's strategy and structure to capture opportunities enabled by digital technology. (Nathan Furr and Andrew Shipilov, Digital Doesn't Have to Be Disruptive, Harvard Business Review 97(4), July/August 2019, pp. 94-103)

ol.li: More ways of interfacing with partners and/or public (inside-out)
Faster flow of change and faster feedback cycles (inside-in)

ul.li: There shouldn't be a standalone API strategy
Business strategy should be driving the digital strategy
Digital strategy should be driving the API strategy
API strategy can always be traced back to business strategy
APIs are popping up like mushrooms
API designers and developers should get support
API consumers should get coherence
API programs often see two development phases

ol.li: Centralization to achieve economies of scale
Decentralization to remove bottlenecks and increase flow

ul.li: Often a side-effect of entering the decentralization phase
Self-service with the goal of increasing developer autonomy and flow
Automating non-differentiating and not-unimportant tasks

slide.title: Know Your Platforms: Different Platform Types

ul.li: API Platform: For external users (partners and/or public)
Internal Developer Platform (IDP): API platform (private) + DevOps tooling
Platform Business: Having a multi-sided business model

slide.title: Conway's Law
slide.blockquote: Any organization that designs a system (defined broadly) will produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure. (Mel Conway)

ul.li: Technical leaders must have a say about organization design
Not all collaboration/communication is good
Four types of teams:
Stream-aligned: Deliver value with minimal hands-offs
Enabling: Grow capabilities of stream-aligned teams
Complicated-subsystem: Reduce cognitive load of stream-aligned teams
Platform: Make stream-aligned teams autonomous
More API teams mean more ways to solve the same problem
Solving API problems is not what teams should focus on
Solving API problems in a consistent way helps the API landscape
Communications across teams is a challenge
Complement channels with documentation of practices

slide.title: The Anatomy of a Good Guideline

ul.li: Why does the guideline exist?
Rationale for creating the guideline
What can be done to address the described issue
At least one good solution for addressing the issue
How to implement the solution
At least one way to use the solution in practice
Testing that the guideline has been followed
Some tests can be automated but many will be by declaration or review
Start capturing feedback from API teams
Challenges along the way
Solutions they have found or implemented
Quantifying the time they spend with cross-cutting vs. domain tasks
Start editing and providing guidance that API teams can find and use
Tooling can be as simple as markdown and shared repositories
